item.title: @iceagefarmer on 2025-09-26 17:11:00+00:00 (#3255)
item.description:
"De-extinction company" Colossal Biosciences has announced that they successfully gene-edited primordial germ cells (PGCs) from a pigeon. Cloning/editing genes of birds is harder than mammals, wherein scientists take an unfertilized egg, remove its nucleus and replace it with the nucleus from a donor body. Birds‚Äô large, opaque eggs, on the other hand, are laid after embryos begin developing, which complicates the approach.
Instead, Colossal plans to inject gene-edited Nicobar germ cells into chicken embryos. These altered chickens would grow up with pigeon-making cells in their ovaries or testes, acting like surrogates. Thus, such a chicken could lay an egg that hatches a pigeon and, after additional gene edits, potentially a dodo-like bird.
and ... they dress it up in "saving the animals" altruism:
‚ÄúBy developing these protocols,‚Äù Shapiro said in the press release, ‚Äúwe‚Äôre establishing crucial biobanking capabilities and opening new possibilities for genetic rescue of endangered species.‚Äù
Honestly, this is like watching a 5-year old play with a nuclear bomb. These scientists have no idea the ramifications of the technology with which they are playing. It will not end well ‚Äî and you can take that to the biobank.
- @iceagefarmer

item.description:
Spying on Farmers? the Global Carbon Compliance Grid:
Years ago I covered an Al Gore-backed project called Climate TRACE, which promised to fuse satellite data and other data sources using AI to "detect greenhouse gas emissions" anywhere in the world. "So we can track down that last cow fart!"
Now, the data is live, and public, with resolution down to 1km¬≤. That means:
- Emissions from individual buildings can be tracked - Fertilizer application ‚Äî especially nitrogen (which they want to ban!) ‚Äî can be inferred from spectral analysis - CROPS can be identified, field by field.
And what's crazy is, not only are they spying on every square kilometer on earth, they are publishing the data for anyone to look at. That means Climate TRACE needn't bother with enforcement; that is left to governments, insurers, or ESG-based funding. Automated fines or denying funding is a mere flip of a switch from here.
BOTTOM LINE: the mechanism to enforce the carbon emissions or fertilizer restrictions that WEF et al are discussing is already in place.
https://climatetrace.org/data

item.title: @iceagefarmer on 2025-08-26 19:12:53+00:00 (#3231)
item.description:
The World Microbiome Partnership (WMP) is an international forum founded in 2023 with funding from the EU Horizon 2020 to create a governance structure for microbiome manipulation across agriculture, medicine, and climate policy.
The WMP is aligned with the One Health and Planetary Health agendas (the same ones behind both the EAT-Lancet commissions "Planetary Health Diet" and the UN's Food Systems Summit that promises to eliminate animal agriculture).
WMP participants include the WHO, the CDC, NIH, and biotech firms. They promote the idea that microbial communities must be governed like other strategic assets.
The key thing to understand is that the technocrats are reframing the microbiome as critical infrastructure: more like an energy grid or communication network than a sacred, living ecosystem.
As biotech companies deploy platforms to build GMO microbes to do everything from "manufacturing", to biomarkers, to surveillance ‚Äî the WMP seeks control of these novel systems, positioning microbial life as programmable, governable...and ultimately weaponizable.

item.description:
Ground beef prices reach record highs as warning issued
Ground beef prices across the U.S. continue to reach new highs, driven by shrinking cattle herds, with looming import restrictions threatening to push costs even higher.
According to government data released last week, the average price of a pound of 100 percent ground beef rose to $6.12 last month, up from $5.98 in May and $5.47 in June 2024. Experts have said this trend shows no signs of slowing, meaning there may be upward pressure on prices through 2026 and beyond.
"It might be at least two to three years before we would see any significant change on the supply side that would ultimately lead to some moderation in beef prices," agricultural economist Derrell Peel told Newsweek.

item.title: @iceagefarmer on 2025-06-23 01:47:46+00:00 (#3206)
item.description:
The closure of the Strait of Hormuz throws the global fertilizer market into a frenzy: roughly 33% of global fertilizer exports‚Äîincluding urea, ammonia, and sulphur‚Äîpass through the strait. For urea:
- Qatar (~13% of global exports) - Saudi Arabia (~11%) - Iran (~10%, and recently shut down completely due to the conflict) - Oman (~8%) - UAE (~4%)
In 2024 China slashed its urea exports by 83% YoY due to new export restrictions.
The net effect of these is that about 40% of the world nitrogen fertilizer supply is suddenly no longer available for export, which has traders at major importers (India, Brazil) panic buying to secure theirs.
Not only does this translate to very real impact on food supply and prices ‚Äî it conveniently aligns with the WEF/UN agenda to "reduce nitrogen pollution..."

item.title: @iceagefarmer on 2025-06-20 22:49:19+00:00 (#3203)
item.description:
The Strait of Hormuz is not just an artery of the global energy system, it is also one of the primary paths in the global food trade system:
- Qatar imports 90% of its food, the bulk of it through the strait. - Bahrain & Kuwait are also reliant on food imports, depending heavily on maritime trade there. - The UAE also imports a large % of food, much of it passing through the strait (although some could re-route to other ports like Fujairah)
- even Iran, ironically, relies on the strait, importing the bulk of its grains and sugar.
The grains mentioned above aren't just for people ‚Äî it's also ANIMAL FEED. In fact, the UAE, Qatar and Kuwait import nearly ALL their animal feed.
So, a closure of the strait‚Äîeven for a time‚Äîcould cause massively cascading problems, the loss of many livestock across the M.E., and spur a global food security crisis.
So ... how's your garden growing this year? Now would be a great time to STOP depending on the system to feed your family.
- @iceagefarmer

item.title: @iceagefarmer on 2022-11-04 14:15:10+00:00 (#3178)
item.description:
France trying desperately to restart nuclear reactors, but labor union strike delaying maintenace!
France generates roughly 70% of its electricity from a nuclear fleet of 56 reactors, all operated by EDF. However, many of them have been closed down for maintenance, some due to corrosion-related issues. Currently, only 31 units are reportedly operating. EDF has pledged to restart all shutdown reactors before winter to avoid power shortages in the country.
However, since October 6, there have been strikes among EDF employees involved in repair work at 19 reactors, delaying maintenance by several weeks.
Last month, the French national electricity grid operator RTE warned that it would not rule out the risk of blackouts this winter due to prolonged strikes halting the repair.
[this announcement, as it is revealed that UK was running drills about managing extended blackouts and resulting crises ‚Ä¶ it is clear what is planned for the #EnergyCrisis]
